message:
Greetings, 
I want to build a "flights search engine" based on human language.
In other words, the user searches for "flights from Cairo to London today.", then the app should find all flights with "Source =Cairo", "destination = London", and "date = Time.Today".

What I have found so far, that this is related to NLP(Natural Language processing), which can do something like identifying of classes of entities within the sentence(determine if it's a location, date, person).

Now, I don't have a clear idea about what to do next, should i use regex intensively, or mix of if & else, or am I on the wrong track?
I would appreciate if you have samples or a simple tutorial to do such thing or more importantly, if there is no sample, ازاى ممكن افكر صح فى حاجة زى كده؟
note: the app will be asp.net, but samples in other languages are welcomed.
Sample of c# library: http://sharpnlp.codeplex.com/
story: Ebram Tharwat shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: SharpNLP - open source natural language processing tools
caption: sharpnlp.codeplex.com
description: English language natural language processing tools written in C#. Centred around a port of the Java OpenNLP library (http://opennlp.sourceforge.net/), which includes a sentence splitter, a tokenizer, a part-of-speech tagger, a chunker (used to "find non-recursive…

data.message:
after you sort out your NLP part you will need a source for the flight data. the QPX api gives you 50 free queries per day.
I suggest you start buy practicing the API. when you are able to use it effectively, move on to the NLP stage to translate the queries to the API calls.
Have you seen any leading website in the world made with asp.net ? I am curious why people use this stuff?

What's wrong with a simple /(.*)\s+to\s+(.*)/ and then comparing with a list of airport names to get the longest right-most match for $1 and the longest left-most match for $2?

For parsing the natural time expressions, you can use Stanford NLP's SUtime.

Do you have any queries in mind where such a simple approach wouldn't suffice?

my graduation project is similar to your project 
we use nlp and semantic web db (dbpedia ) 
and the project is written in python
